headline: The Whole Story with Anderson Cooper
subHeadline: The Reign Begins: Charles and Camilla. Aired 8-9p ET

utterances.speaker: JIM ACOSTA, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: But I'll be back here next weekend. I'll see you then. In the meantime, that's the news. Reporting from Washington, I'm Jim Acosta. Have a great week, everybody. Thanks so much for tuning in and we'll see you soon. Have a good night.ANDERSON COOPER, CNN ANCHOR (voice-over): Coming up.

utterances.speaker: KATE WILLIAMS, CNN HISTORIAN AND ROYAL EXPERT
utterances.sentences: King Charles is a man with a battle on his hands.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: On THE WHOLE STORY.

utterances.speaker: CAMILLA TOMINEY, ASSOCIATE EDITOR, THE DAILY TELEGRAPH
utterances.sentences: The king is acutely aware that they're only there for as long as the public wants them to be there.AILSA ANDERSON, COMMUNICATIONS AND PRESS SECRETARY, QUEEN ELIZABETH II, 2001-2013: The institution is so unique.

utterances.speaker: ERICA HILL, CNN ANCHOR AND NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Do you ever imagine that the monarchy would go away?COOPER (on-camera): Good evening and welcome to THE WHOLE STORY. I'm Anderson Cooper. Final preparations are underway in the United Kingdom right now for the coronation of King Charles III and his wife, Camilla, the queen consort. It's a ceremony steeped in tradition with some of the rituals dating back nearly a thousand years. It's only been televised once, however, when Queen Elizabeth II was crowned nearly 70 years ago. She was one of the longest serving and most celebrated monarchs in British history but her son faces a different type of reign. The royal family is splintered and with a new and less popular monarch on the throne, many are questioning the role of this royal institution. CNN's Erica Hill traveled to London to meet with leading British scholars, journalists, and those close to the royal family to better understand what this moment and this man mean in a modern world. "The Reign Begins: Charles and Camilla." (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: MAX FOSTER, CNN ROYAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: The queen has died, very sadly. CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR, CNN CHIEF INTERNATIONAL ANCHORthis country has only known a queen.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEW CHANCE, CNN SENIOR INTERNATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: King Charles III is taking over.

utterances.speaker: FOSTER
utterances.sentences: Long live the king.HILL (voice-over): For centuries, London reigned as a global center. For finance, for theater, for thought. Today, there is an undeniable energy, from south London's vibrant Brixton neighborhood to the streets and shops of trendy soho. Its palaces and history still a major draw, no matter the weather.

utterances.speaker: BIDISHA MAMATA, BROADCASTER AND JOURNALIST
utterances.sentences: Everything begins and ends here at Buckingham Palace. Oh, it's the changing of the guard.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Much like the changing of the guard, the British monarchy has been steadfast. Loyal to its role on this island and beyond.ROBERT LACEY, HISTORICAL CONSULTANT, "THE CROWN": In the past, it represented power. Nowadays it's supposed to represent shared values.

utterances.speaker: KEHINDE ANDREWS, PROFESSOR OF BLACK STUDIES, BIRMINGHAM CITY UNIVERSITY
utterances.sentences: The idea that they bring us all together in shared values is frankly not true. I mean, not in my --

utterances.speaker: LACEY
utterances.sentences: It's supposed to. I'm not --

utterances.speaker: ANDREWS
utterances.sentences: It's supposed to be. It doesn't --

utterances.speaker: LACEY
utterances.sentences: I'm not saying -- we are here debating whether that's true or not.

utterances.speaker: ANDREWS
utterances.sentences: But it's never been true. Most people in Britain and the empire probably don't have that relationship and don't think it's shared values.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: British scholars Kehinde Andrews, Kate Williams, Helen Carr, and Robert Lacey came ready for that debate and more.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The queen's monarchy was the high watermark of monarchy.

utterances.speaker: KING CHARLES III, UNITED KINGDOM
utterances.sentences: Queen Elizabeth was a life well lived.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: We'll never have monarchy, I would say, again in terms of such impact and such world influence and talked about so much. I think things are definitely changing.

utterances.speaker: HELEN CARR, COLUMNIST, BBC HISTORY MAGAZINE
utterances.sentences: Over the last century with the advent of the internet, social media, everything has become so much more global. And I think young people who are growing up in that world, that very connected world, are starting to ask bigger questions. UNIDENTIFIED FEMALEpoint anymore. I don't wish them any harm. They're -- they're fine. Just I don't want to be part of it. HILL (on-camera): How do you feel about the monarchy?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I think of the history because I'm from Ghana, so I kind of think of the colonization and things like that.HILL (voice-over): At its height a century ago, the British empire was the largest and most powerful the world had ever seen. King George V ruled over 74 countries and territories counting 458 million people as his subjects.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: We are in flux in this country between do we acknowledge slavery, do we acknowledge empire, do we acknowledge how much that has made this country, you know, this tiny, tiny country one of the most richest and most powerful countries in the world? Or do we carry on with the idea of fair play and railways and that, you know, British influence is always benevolent?

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: In 2023, just how much can King Charles put right? How much of these imperfections does he need to address to keep this royal institution alive?

utterances.speaker: KING CHARLES III
utterances.sentences: I want to acknowledge that the roots of our contemporary association run deep into the most painful period of our history. I cannot describe the depths of my personal sorrow at the suffering of so many, as I continue to deepen my own understanding of slavery's enduring impact.

utterances.speaker: JACK ROYSTON, CHIEF ROYAL CORRESPONDENT, NEWSWEEK
utterances.sentences: He's gone somewhere already, but he's acknowledged the hurt that people feel, but the key sticking point, is what's wanted is an apology.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: In early April, the king agreed to open the royal archives to researchers looking into the monarchy's ties to slavery.

utterances.speaker: MAMATA
utterances.sentences: What people are asking of the royal family now is simply, what do you stand for? What are you going to do with all your money and privilege and visibility?

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: His former communications secretary, Kristina Kyriacou, says the king has been preparing for those questions for decades.KRISTINA KYRIACOU, ADVISER, COMMUNICATIONS SECRETARY TO KING CHARLES 2009-2016: He sees himself as in a position where he can be the great convener, the great mediator, the interjectory, the person who brings something to the fore.

utterances.speaker: KING CHARLES III
utterances.sentences: The commonwealth has been a constant in my own life. It shares scale, challenges us to unite and be bold.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: While many are hopeful that King Charles can achieve those goals --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I think hopefully he will do a good job. He's quite beloved in this country.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: His own history presents an unavoidable hurdle for the new monarch.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: It's just that we've gotten used to Queen Elizabeth and for it to also be a man that's not very well liked in the world, I guess, because of the whole Diana-Camilla thing.

utterances.speaker: MAMATA
utterances.sentences: With King Charles, his dirty and clean laundry has been in public for decades now.

utterances.speaker: ANDREWS
utterances.sentences: The queen was popular because we didn't know anything about it. Don't know anything about it all. Whereas Prince Charles, we already know too much about him.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: It's impossible to talk about Charles without mentioning the late Princess Diana.

utterances.speaker: SARAH HEWSON, ROYAL EDITOR, TALK TV
utterances.sentences: The Charles and Diana story was the fairy tale that turned into the nightmare that ultimately turned into the tragedy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I cannot believe what he has done.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: He's really shown what he truly is like and that is someone who is a cheat.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: British journalist Sarah Hewson, Bidisha Mamata, and Jack Royston, and Camilla Tominey have covered the royals for decades.

utterances.speaker: ROYSTON
utterances.sentences: We went back to old Poland from this era. Back in 1991, so this is one year before his affair with Camilla first became public knowledge. As many as 82 percent of the British public thought he'd make a good king. By the time they divorced in 1946, only 41 percent of British people thought that he would make a good king.

utterances.speaker: KYRIACOU
utterances.sentences: Sometimes in life, and definitely in the royal family, you're born into roles that are very set piece. You're born into roles that sort of have a template, a historical template. And I think sometimes it must be very difficult. What is absolute fact is that he tried to change that for both of his sons.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: When we return, King Charles the rebel?

utterances.speaker: ROYSTON
utterances.sentences: Charles had points when he was absolutely raging against the machine in exactly the same way Harry did.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: He was ahead of his time.

utterances.speaker: KYRIACOU
utterances.sentences: He's ahead of his time, Ailsa. ANDERSON

utterances.speaker: KYRIACOU
utterances.sentences: Ahead of his time.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: And later.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: King Charles is a man with a battle on his hands.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: The fight to save the monarchy.

utterances.speaker: ERIN BURNETT, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: A dramatic and shocking announcement --

utterances.speaker: JOHN BERMAN, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Royal drama in the United Kingdom.

utterances.speaker: HEWSON
utterances.sentences: We're seeing the departure of Harry and Meghan hitting them hard.

utterances.speaker: PRINCE HARRY, DUKE OF SUSSEX
utterances.sentences: To see this institutional gaslighting, that is extraordinary.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: People were very excited that perhaps the royal family was reflecting a multicultural country.

utterances.speaker: ANDREWS
utterances.sentences: Even when it is in their interest, clearly, blatantly in their interest to use this couple to promote their agenda, still can't do.

utterances.speaker: CARR
utterances.sentences: I think that is a huge missed opportunity.HILL (on-camera): Is there any way to get some of that opportunity back?

utterances.speaker: CARR
utterances.sentences: That's difficult to say.

utterances.speaker: TOMINEY
utterances.sentences: Look, they're not a nuclear family. They're to some extent a thermonuclear one?HILL (voice-over): In the three years since Harry and Meghan announced they were stepping back from their royal duties --

utterances.speaker: ALISYN CAMEROTA, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Buckingham Palace has been blindsided by Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's announcement that they are quitting their royal roles.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: -- the spotlight on this family has only grown.

utterances.speaker: OPRAH WINFREY, TV HOST
utterances.sentences: There's a conversation about how dark your baby is going to be?

utterances.speaker: MEGHAN MARKLE, DUCHESS OF SUSSEX
utterances.sentences: Potentially. And what that would mean or look like.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: British journalist Camilla Tominey broke the news of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's relationship. She says, despite the outrage, Harry's public push for a different royal path feels familiar.

utterances.speaker: TOMINEY
utterances.sentences: There is a great deal of similarity, I think, between the prince of Wales at times raging against the machine and saying, well, I want to do this, and I want to talk about that, and by the way, I know what I'm talking about, and I'm not afraid to say it. Who does that remind you of? Reminds me massively of Harry.HILL (on-camera): In his book "Spare," Harry writes that Charles had always been discouraged from hard work, he told me. He'd been advised that the heir shouldn't do too much. Shouldn't try too hard for fear of outshining the monarch, but he'd rebelled. Is Charles a rebel? Does anyone feel he is?

utterances.speaker: CARR
utterances.sentences: I wouldn't call him a rebel. I think that he has developed a sense of self-awareness, and gone at things in a different way, but I wouldn't say that that would be -- I wouldn't call that rebelling.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think he'd like to see himself as a rebel and revolutionary.

utterances.speaker: ANDREWS
utterances.sentences: King Charles is not a rebellion, certainly not revolutionary. I wish he was, but I doubt he'll do anything to rock the boat.

utterances.speaker: ROYSTON
utterances.sentences: Charles had points when he was absolutely raging against the machine in exactly the same way Harry did. There are so many parallels.

utterances.speaker: ABBY PHILLIP, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Prince Harry's new book makes it clear why there was no happily ever after for him if he stayed inside those palace walls.HILL (voice-over): Nearly 30 years before "Spare," a bombshell biography of then Prince Charles pulled back the curtain on his own difficult upbringing. The authorized book detailing unresolved issues between Charles and his parents, including the emotional gulf between him and his mother, describing Queen Elizabeth as detached and recounting how his father, Prince Philip, thought Charles was a bit of a wimp as a child and bullied him, often bringing him to tears, particularly at social gatherings. As for finding that hard work, that act of rebellion Harry talks about, it was also about finding a purpose as the monarch-in-waiting.

utterances.speaker: LACEY
utterances.sentences: As a young man, he had to look around for causes to support that were not political. And I think we forget that back in the day, to fight for the environment or try and save the planet was so off the wall, it wasn't a political issue.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: His passion for the environment has driven Charles for decades.

utterances.speaker: KING CHARLES III
utterances.sentences: I've been, I'm afraid, at this for rather a long time.

utterances.speaker: HEWSON
utterances.sentences: He was deemed as being completely bonkers for talking to his plants, for holistic well-being, for example. And yet all of those issues have now come into the mainstream. Look at where we are on climate change now.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Ailsa Anderson, Charles Anson, and Kristina Kyriacou saw many of those moments and those issues up close during their time working for the royal family.

utterances.speaker: KYRIACOU
utterances.sentences: He mentioned organic farming in 1971. And all people did for the next 30 years was ridicule him.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: But he was ahead of his time.

utterances.speaker: KYRIACOU
utterances.sentences: He was ahead of his time, Ailsa. Ahead of his time.

utterances.speaker: KING CHARLES III
utterances.sentences: Things don't stand still. And it's very possible that we get left behind if we're not always trying to see where the next challenge is coming from.CHARLES ANSON, PRESS SECRETARY TO QUEEN ELIZABETH II, 1990-1997: I think there's a natural energy in someone like the king, who is very proud and loves his country. He has a strong sort of sense of humanity as a whole.

utterances.speaker: KYRIACOU
utterances.sentences: Charles is a passionate man. He's an empathetic man. He's a sensitive man. And those adjectives that I've used to describe him already should give people the sense that he can be hotheaded.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: That passion fueling a series of letters, the so-called "Black Spider memos," sent to senior government officials in the early 2000s with policy demands on key issues, like the Iraq war, a move seen by many as drifting into politics, breaking with royal protocol.

utterances.speaker: LACEY
utterances.sentences: The black spider came from the reference to his handwriting. He'd get a letter typed and then he couldn't resist scribbling all sorts of points in it. And when he was taxed on this, he would say rather defiantly, this is what ordinary people said to me. So I'm passing it on to you politicians who should know about it.

utterances.speaker: ROYSTON
utterances.sentences: The man is legitimately a workaholic and has a kind of deeply philosophical profound belief in work, like the Prince's Trust, which actually he sets up to try and help young people from disadvantaged backgrounds find work.

utterances.speaker: KING CHARLES III
utterances.sentences: We are committed to helping young people achieve their ambitions.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Charles established that charity in the 1970s after serving in the Royal Navy.

utterances.speaker: HEWSON
utterances.sentences: He set that up with his Navy severance pay. 7,400 pounds that he put into 21 community projects and it's grown now in the form of the Prince's Trust as we now know it to support over a million disadvantaged young people, and among them, the Hollywood actor, Idris Elba.

utterances.speaker: IDRIS ALBA, ACTOR
utterances.sentences: I came up in the Prince's Trust. I actually auditioned for a grant and they gave me a grant.

utterances.speaker: TOMINEY
utterances.sentences: He's always sort of talked in terms of leaving a legacy, when he said he hoped that he would leave the world in a better place than he had found it, that he's quite genuine in that endeavor.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: And yet, despite those efforts, there seemed to be no escaping the turmoil of the '90s.

utterances.speaker: MAMATA
utterances.sentences: Diana looms enormously over the entire story. You have people who weren't even alive when Diana was alive talking about her as if she's the new Marilyn Monroe figure of the U.K.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Diana is surging on TikTok, partly due to her advocacy for AIDS and the early discussing about the LGBTQ community and that's why Diana's legacy is so powerful in terms of what she did, in terms of who she was, and she is always someone who when people see Charles, they think about.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We have some very sad news to bring you.

utterances.speaker: KYRIACOU
utterances.sentences: The aftermath of the death of Diana was something that was felt around the globe, to have died so young, so tragically, such a vibrant figure.

utterances.speaker: CARR
utterances.sentences: And the sort of absolute grief that overcame the country was quite extraordinary.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It was extraordinary. People were like, men, women, children tears flowing down their faces.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: That grief resonating with a new generation, in large part due to the popularity of "The Crown."

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: And I think that people out there can sense that I have suffered.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: And Prince Harry's ongoing pain.

utterances.speaker: PRINCE HARRY
utterances.sentences: I could no face the reality that she was gone.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The blame lies with King Charles, and therefore Camilla was kind of to blame, but also dragged through the mud a bit.HILL (on-camera): How do you feel about Camilla?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I would prefer Diana, I guess. But she's fine.

utterances.speaker: TOMINEY
utterances.sentences: I remember having a conversation with the queen consort about being called Camilla, because, obviously, we're both called Camilla, and then I remarked that not many people were called Camilla these days, which then she remarked might have been because of her.(LAUGHTER) HILL (voice-over): Ahead, why the woman who was once among Britain's most hated is now seen as the king's biggest asset.

utterances.speaker: KYRIACOU
utterances.sentences: She rules with an iron rod with him.HILL (on-camera): She keeps him in line?

utterances.speaker: KYRIACOU
utterances.sentences: Oh, my goodness.HILL (voice-over): An evolution with its own share of drama.

utterances.speaker: TOMINEY
utterances.sentences: Most people look upon the king and queen consort as a couple and say, well, they arguably should have probably been together from the beginning.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Instead, getting to that point took decades at a very public toll. Years before a shy Diana Spencer was introduced to the world, it was Camilla Shant who caught the eye of the prince of Wales. The two first met in 1970.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Had Charles married Camilla in the first place, she would be seen as a popular consort.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Charles joined the Navy in 1971 and while he was at sea, Camilla became engaged to Andrew Parker Bowles. But that wasn't the only complication. For a man born to be king, the requirements for his future queen were clear. An aristocratic bloodline and virginity. Love was far less important.

utterances.speaker: KYRIACOU
utterances.sentences: It must be very difficult to say, I, perhaps, would like to follow a different path. And so perhaps, in the mele of all of that, Charles wasn't strong enough to say what he really wanted. But he tried to change that for both of his sons. He allowed them to choose freely who they love.HILL (on-camera): Standing on this bridge, we are in the center of truly all things British.

utterances.speaker: ANSON
utterances.sentences: You see Buckingham Palace at the other end of the lake, horse guards where the trooping of the color ceremony takes place. And then, of course, Westminster Abbey through the trees.HILL (voice-over): Charles Anson was Queen Elizabeth's press secretary from 1990 to 1997. (On-camera): The years that you were there were some of the most difficult years. So you had the tapes.

utterances.speaker: ANSON
utterances.sentences: It was a period of huge change in terms of communication, the sophistication of being able to bug people's phones and so on. So that when those tapes emerged like that, clearly illegally taped conversations, I was in a very tricky position and I didn't feel there was any alternative but simply not make a comment.HILL (voice-over): Those tapes were recordings of a private explicit phone call between Charles and Camilla in 1989, when both were still married. The transcripts published four years later rocked the country. The tabloid-ready details, including the now infamous moment Charles told Camilla he wished to live inside her trousers quickly became known as Camillagate.

utterances.speaker: TOMINEY
utterances.sentences: You look at the Camillagates and you feel that you've perhaps passed the point of no return. It happened at a time when there was a huge amount of gossip around this forbidden love triangle of the royal family. And that is very adult. It's dark, it's deep, it's scintillating gossip.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It was only a matter of time before the tabloids printed what's been circulating in private for days.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The first complete transcript of the so-called Camillagate tape.

utterances.speaker: TOMINEY
utterances.sentences: It was so damaging because there was an extent to which it depicted the king in a ridiculous and preposterous light.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Charles admitted to the affair a year later. A moment made all the more dramatic in "The Crown" on Netflix.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Did you at least try to be faithful from the start?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes. Until it became obvious that the marriage couldn't be saved.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Words that only seemed to strengthen support for Princess Diana and disdain for the prince of Wales.

utterances.speaker: ROYSTON
utterances.sentences: Charles fell from grace during the Diana era in quite a spectacular way.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Camilla was the other villain in this story.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: In the wake of Princess Diana's death, it appeared the public would never accept Parker-Bowles.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: The woman who 30 years later is now queen.

utterances.speaker: TOMINEY
utterances.sentences: The biggest irony, of course, is that of all of the royals, arguably the most friendly towards the press is the queen consort, the woman who has been most destroyed by the press.

utterances.speaker: LACEY
utterances.sentences: She was portrayed as a wicked, scheming woman who was breaking up the royal marriage. I think that was unfair to her. I mean, it was Charles who broke up that marriage. And he wanted a Camilla, not a Diana.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Queen Elizabeth finally gave her blessing for Charles and Diana to divorce in 1996. Just a year before Diana's tragic death.

utterances.speaker: JIM CLANCY, FORMER CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Princess Diana has been killed in a car crash in Paris.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: While Camilla had remained by his side privately, it would take time and careful choreography for her to join him publicly.

utterances.speaker: KING CHARLES III
utterances.sentences: Suddenly you find yourself, you know, on the public stage, it is a challenge and if you've not found yourself in that position before, you can imagine it is a real challenge.

utterances.speaker: KYRIACOU
utterances.sentences: It was a very, very turbulent time, but a lot of what happened during that time was very much from her sensibility. That she shouldn't in any way be overt.HILL (on-camera): Was there a role from the press office in helping with Camilla's image? How much would the queen's press office have played a role in some of those decisions? How closely would the offices work together?

utterances.speaker: ANSON
utterances.sentences: Very closely together, indeed. And I think in the early stages of their relationship, the palace was keen to take it at a measured rate and not sort of do too much at one time.HILL (voice-over): In his book and in an interview with Anderson Cooper on "60 Minutes," Prince Harry says that measured campaign made his future stepmother dangerous. COOPER (on-camera): How is she dangerous?

utterances.speaker: PRINCE HARRY
utterances.sentences: Because of the need for her to rehabilitate her image. HILLfather's, came at the expense of bad press for Harry and William, and that Camilla, quote, "sacrificed me on her personal PR altar."

utterances.speaker: TOMINEY
utterances.sentences: There was definitely an attempt to rehabilitate the king's image and indeed that of her, his girlfriend, as she was at the time, because she was public enemy number one. There's no doubt about it.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: The view from inside the palace? Not surprisingly a bit different.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: The institution is so unique, there's so much that other people outside wouldn't understand, but we do.

utterances.speaker: KYRIACOU
utterances.sentences: The very notion that those people employed in the royal households would set the family members up against each other and start telling me about negative stories about different -- I was quite horrified. It's not something that I had ever witnessed.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON
utterances.sentences: I totally agree with that.

utterances.speaker: ANSON
utterances.sentences: Absolutely the same. As a family, they needed to stand together as much as possible. Of course there would be tensions.

utterances.speaker: CAMILLA, QUEEN CONSORT OF THE UNITED KINGDOM
utterances.sentences: Hello? How are you? Nice to see you. Hi. Hi.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: When we return --

utterances.speaker: MAMATA
utterances.sentences: Her great task now is to show everyone around her and the public, look, I am here for a reason. I didn't just home wreck this family and be part of a horrible, weird, Greek tragedy.

utterances.speaker: CARR
utterances.sentences: And she's been a real rock and a support.

utterances.speaker: HEWSON
utterances.sentences: Members of the royal household will know that if you want something done, you have a quiet word in the ear of the queen consort. She'll say, leave it with me. And she'll then make sure that it happens. And that the king is onboard.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: It's been nearly 20 years since Charles and Camilla were married.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And there you see them, now married. You can see the gold ring on Camilla's hand.

utterances.speaker: KING CHARLES III
utterances.sentences: It's always nice to have somebody on your side. We laugh a lot because she sees the funny side of life.

utterances.speaker: HEWSON
utterances.sentences: When we talk about Camilla and her PR, it was a slow, steady playing the long game, from public enemy number one to where she is now, soon to be queen, crowned in Westminster Abbey.

utterances.speaker: TOMINEY
utterances.sentences: She's got a consciousness about her public image.

utterances.speaker: CAMILLA
utterances.sentences: What is going on in history class?

utterances.speaker: TOMINEY
utterances.sentences: I think she's also conscious perhaps of her husband's ego or indeed the ego of the institution of royalty, to which she belongs.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Charles was very jealous of Diana's popularity.

utterances.speaker: LACEY
utterances.sentences: I think the reason Camilla fits in better with him than Diana did is because she doesn't upstage him.HILL (on-camera): How responsible is she for what has changed in terms of the perception toward Charles? Did she help?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think certainly, she acts as a calming influence to Charles. She's there when things are getting a little bit fraught, tempers may be frayed. And we saw it played out in the days after the queen's death.

utterances.speaker: KING CHARLES III
utterances.sentences: Oh, my god. I hate this.

utterances.speaker: CAMILLA
utterances.sentences: Oh, look, it's going everywhere. Hang on. Has anybody got --

utterances.speaker: HEWSON
utterances.sentences: And when the pens weren't working or the ink was going everywhere.

utterances.speaker: KING CHARLES III
utterances.sentences: I can't bear this bloody thing. What they do every stinking time.

utterances.speaker: HEWSON
utterances.sentences: There she was, calming him down. That it's all right. Let's change the pen.

utterances.speaker: KING CHARLES III
utterances.sentences: It's always nice to have somebody who, you know, you feel understands and wants to encourage and, you know, certainly poke fun if I get too serious about it.

utterances.speaker: KYRIACOU
utterances.sentences: One thing that we see from the queen consort, Camilla, that she rules with an iron rod with him.HILL (on-camera): She keeps him in line.

utterances.speaker: KYRIACOU
utterances.sentences: Oh, my goodness, absolutely. She has very much been the driving force, trying to get some work-life balance into his life.HILL (voice-over): In a family brimming with very public turmoil, King Charles may need Camilla's steady hand more than ever. WILLIAMS: Let's face it, what kind of relationship does he have with Andrew? I mean, Andrew is accused of being a criminal. He didn't have a good relationship with his parents. He has a sticky relationship with his children. Camilla is his rock. And he is -- he is very reliant on her.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Prince Andrew was once second in line to the throne. A helicopter pilot, rumored to be the queen's favorite child, until his stunning fall from grace amid claims of sexual abuse.

utterances.speaker: MICHAEL HOLMES, CNN INTERNATIONAL ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Prince Andrews speaks out about his ties to Jeffrey Epstein and allegations he had sex with an underage girl.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: While he has repeatedly denied the accusations, Andrew was stripped of his royal duties and military titles, the son noting the queen had effectively banished him. A civil suit filed by his accuser in 2021 was settled in early 2022 with no admission of guilt or wrongdoing.

utterances.speaker: ROYSTON
utterances.sentences: The monarchy was slow to take action on Prince Andrew. And he should have had his honorary patronages revoked way sooner. You know, Harry's and Meghan's were revoked before Andrew's were. And honestly that is a stain on the reputation of the monarchy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: How damaging he is to the monarchy? This is a big headache for the coronation. I think people accepted that he was there in the queen's funeral. He is the queen's son. But simply Andrew couldn't be more toxic.

utterances.speaker: CARR
utterances.sentences: It's incendiary. I think that's one of the key contentions really, isn't it? But nobody really covers Andrew much in comparison to Meghan, who gets covered all the time. And that is problematic. That's deeply problematic because you have this person who is connected to all of this evil and wrong and yet that is less important somehow than a black woman as part of the royal family. And that is --HILL (on-camera): That is stark contrast.

utterances.speaker: CARR
utterances.sentences: It's a stark contrast.HILL (voice-over): Scandals, real and imagined, dominate the royal headlines.

utterances.speaker: MAMATA
utterances.sentences: I think the relationship between the press and the royal family has actually not changed. Because they want to be seen, they want to be talked about. But only in a good light. HILLtree that falls in the forest. If it's not heard, does it make a sound? They have no point unless they are seen.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: They have to be in the press because you're not there to be seen, you don't exist.HILL (voice-over): Controlling when and how they're seen is a lot more difficult in 2023. And not just because everyone is a photographer.

utterances.speaker: ANDREWS
utterances.sentences: Part of the problem that the monarchy has in relation to the press is, this is built on an old model. A wall of silence, making them get what they want. But Harry and Meghan had shown, you can't do that anymore. You've got Netflix, you've got Spotify, you've got book deals. There's no far too much of them.

utterances.speaker: HEWSON
utterances.sentences: That relationship between the royal family and the media is a complex difficult, at times relationship, that they need the media, the media needs them. They don't like what each other's doing all the time.

utterances.speaker: ANSON
utterances.sentences: At the end of the day, the monarchy's got to perform in a way that attracts public support.

utterances.speaker: PRINCE HARRY
utterances.sentences: Hi, guys.

utterances.speaker: SARA SIDNER, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Prince Harry will attend his father's coronation.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Public support can be fickle.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: He's going to be doing so, alone.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: His wife, Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, will not join him.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Public feuds, downright disastrous.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It could be that there's still a huge amount of tension between Meghan and the rest of the family.

utterances.speaker: KYRIACOU
utterances.sentences: What I would say definitely with his majesty is that he was always very keen to bring it back to their core business, which was serving members of the public. That was often the benchmark for us. Is it a public matter? Is it a private matter? If it's a private matter, in general, no, don't comment.HILL (on-camera): So what I'm hearing in all of this is, don't expect to hear anything from the king about whether he and Harry are going to reconcile. Is that what I should take from that?

utterances.speaker: KYRIACOU
utterances.sentences: Well, with I think so.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: That is a question I think a lot of people have.

utterances.speaker: KYRIACOU
utterances.sentences: I absolutely think so.

utterances.speaker: ANSON
utterances.sentences: You'll never get rid of gossip and gossip is a trait in every single culture.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Thank you, sir.

utterances.speaker: ANSON
utterances.sentences: But equally, I think all families have their difficulties that they've got to deal with.HILL (voice-over): Still to come, as the monarchy shrinks, could even bigger changes lie ahead?

utterances.speaker: ROYSTON
utterances.sentences: In Britain, it has caused a swing in opinion among 18 to 24- year-olds, specifically.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I don't care for the monarchy. I feel like there's no point in them.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I'm not sure how it's used in modern society.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I don't think we should have a monarchy anymore.HILL (on-camera): Do you ever imagine that the monarchy would go away?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: It could happen.

utterances.speaker: ROYSTON
utterances.sentences: Privilege is going out of fashion really fast. We're in the eat-the-rich era. You know, the history of colonialism and slavery is a major problem. So the chessboard is stacked against them.

utterances.speaker: ANDREWS
utterances.sentences: The whole world debacle around them, the debacle in all this has turned into relief and (INAUDIBLE). Haven't really changed much of the life.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Is there an opportunity for King Charles to lead more in that discussion?

utterances.speaker: ANDREWS
utterances.sentences: I think we have to accept him. One of the primary functions of the royal family today is symbolic. And it was to be a symbol of (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: LACEY
utterances.sentences: Prince Charles -- King Charles, sorry, was sitting at this table now, he would take great exception to that remark. When this issue rose with the royal family, William made a point of breaking the protocol.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAM, PRINCE OF WALES
utterances.sentences: We're very much not a racist family.

utterances.speaker: LACEY
utterances.sentences: You may disagree. Many people would disagree. But that is his declared line.

utterances.speaker: HEWSON
utterances.sentences: We're seeing a shift in the generations, which is we're not just going to sit back silently now and take this. There are times when we have to speak out. And if they don't, they're no longer irrelevant.

utterances.speaker: ANDREWS
utterances.sentences: But if you're going to move on then you have to deal with the problem. There's nothing they can do other than (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: TOMINEY
utterances.sentences: The king's acutely aware, like his late mother was, that they're only there for as long as the public wants them to be.

utterances.speaker: ROYSTON
utterances.sentences: In Britain, among 18 to 24-year-olds, where now more than 50 percent would support abolishing the monarchy.HILL (on-camera): The way I understand it, there's no real rule about how the U.K. would go about abolishing the monarchy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: We have no constitution. This is one of our questions. Unlike so many other countries that have monarchies, head of state, have constitutions. So that political world has to be there to abolish the monarchy.

utterances.speaker: ROYSTON
utterances.sentences: The current generation are about to go through a cost-of- living crisis. It's his problem right now. In the future, it might actually be William's problem.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Everybody is really struggling now with the economy and the cost of living. So to see that amount of money spent on medieval ritual, that really impacts zero on everyday people's lives, just seems a little bit sickening.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: It feels very extravagant.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: But it's not just about the coronation. A message King Charles seems to understand.

utterances.speaker: LACEY
utterances.sentences: Charles always had this idea, a monarchy that costs less and involves less people on the balcony.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: And there's inspiration to be found in some of Europe's other aging monarchies, like Sweden, where in 2019 the king cut five of his grandchildren from the taxpayer funded payroll.

utterances.speaker: HEWSON
utterances.sentences: Charles has to look at this and has to think about this in his role as preserving the monarchy for the next generation. For William, for George, and whether or not he can preserve it.

utterances.speaker: KING CHARLES III
utterances.sentences: Very nice having grandchildren, actually, I think. And it's very odd that you can't believe it's happening to you. It's rather fun to get down on the floor and do silly things with them.

utterances.speaker: TOMINEY
utterances.sentences: People might say, well, hang on. No, we expect George, Charlotte, and Louie to have proper jobs and maybe a little bit of royal work on the side. And somehow the monarchy is going to have to adapt to that.HILL (on-camera): A lot can change in 20 years. (Voice-over): Of course, there's a big difference between a leaner lineup of royals and none at all. And even the staunchest critics believe abolishing the British monarchy is unlikely.

utterances.speaker: ANDREWS
utterances.sentences: The monarchy is very popular. (INAUDIBLE) going to say about it, as much a critique I can give to it, it is still very, very popular.

utterances.speaker: MAMATA
utterances.sentences: There will never not be a monarchy in the U.K. So, the question has to be, both for the public and the royals, what are you here for? And what are you going to do with all of this extraordinary privilege and power and wealth that you have?

utterances.speaker: HEWSON
utterances.sentences: I think what we're seeing is him trying to carve out that role where he stands, how far he can go. And time will tell whether or not he is able to continue to make a difference in the same way. I think he has to do that in a quieter way behind closed doors by bringing others together.

utterances.speaker: MAMATA
utterances.sentences: But I like that about him. I like the fact that I imagine him reading the sort of king terms and conditions every night going like --

utterances.speaker: HEWSON
utterances.sentences: And thinking, OK, how can I push this?

utterances.speaker: MAMATA
utterances.sentences: Where's the loophole in this?HILL (on-camera): Is there a handbook for being king?

utterances.speaker: MAMATA
utterances.sentences: Don't know.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Definitely not.

utterances.speaker: HEWSON
utterances.sentences: When it comes to this legacy, people are looking beyond the king. They are looking to the prince and princess of Wales and their role in the future of the monarchy is absolutely pivotal. The most important player in the House of Windsor right now is Kate and has been for some time because her positioning and the extra kind of sprinkling of stardust that she brings to proceedings, to what is now an all-male line of succession for some time to come. And it's going to be the positioning of the Wales' children as well.HILL (voice-over): Of course it's possible those young heirs decide they don't want a royal life. It wouldn't be the first time.

utterances.speaker: CARR
utterances.sentences: There have been many crises throughout the history of monarchy. And it is something that is, I believe, going to continue until there is a (INAUDIBLE) monarchy and a monarch that decides, this isn't for me, or enough is enough. That now is the time to end this. But also I question sort of who would that be? That's a significant lineage to end.

utterances.speaker: LACEY
utterances.sentences: There might be someone who says there, but there might be a brother or cousin who says, I'll do the job. And then --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: CARR
utterances.sentences: Which to be fair, if we're going to back and looking at what's happened in history, that would certainly be the case.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Barring any defectors, the future is clear for at least two more generations.
